A simple spatialization example using agrometeoR

Thomas Goossens

11/22/2018

Source: vignettes/spatialization_example.Rmd
spatialization_example.Rmd

Load the libraries

# loading mlr & agrometeoR
library(mlr)
## Loading required package: ParamHelpers
library(agrometeoR)

Create the machine learning task for a specific hour

Check the default values of the params in the references file to make sure you understand what is constructed

# create the task
task = makeTask(date = "2017-03-04T15:00:00Z")
## Your API URL call is :  https://app.pameseb.be/agromet/api/v2/cleandata/tsa/1,4,7,9,10,13,14,15,17,18,19,23,24,25,26,27,29,30,32,33,34,35,37,38,39,40,41,42,61/2017-03-04T15:00:00Z/2017-03-04T15:00:00Z  
## The API responded with a status code 200. 
##  Data has been downloaded 
## Data is stored in a list with 2 df elements. 
##  stations_meta.df contains the metadata and records.df contains the stations records.
# what are the variables ? 
colnames(mlr::getTaskData(task$task))
## [1] "elevation" "X"         "Y"         "tsa"
# what data do we have ? 
head(getTaskData(task$task))
##   elevation        X        Y  tsa
## 1  475.4301 721240.2 568849.6  8.4
## 2  343.1246 714221.2 543453.8  7.1
## 3  348.5109 750500.7 550825.6  8.9
## 4  497.0389 753130.6 581716.9 11.2
## 5  389.6670 734687.9 580969.6 11.0
## 6  259.5348 641664.8 588814.6  9.0
task$insights
##    elevation            X                Y               tsa      
##  Min.   : 49.25   Min.   :574629   Min.   :525914   Min.   : 6.7  
##  1st Qu.:147.34   1st Qu.:678027   1st Qu.:588815   1st Qu.:10.6  
##  Median :242.39   Median :712454   Median :621625   Median :11.3  
##  Mean   :270.45   Mean   :704007   Mean   :611498   Mean   :11.0  
##  3rd Qu.:348.51   3rd Qu.:737506   3rd Qu.:636932   3rd Qu.:12.0  
##  Max.   :623.48   Max.   :783160   Max.   :656366   Max.   :14.3

Train a learner

# instantiate a multiple li,near regression learner and specify that it must also provide se of preds
learner = mlr::makeLearner("regr.lm", id = "multipleLinearReg", predict.type = "se" )
# create the model by training the learner and also benchmark the learner with a LOO
model = makeModel(task = task$task, learner = learner)
# what are the model performances ? 
model$perfs$agg
##              task.id        learner.id rmse.test.rmse mse.test.mean
## 1 2017-03-04T150000Z multipleLinearReg      0.8650726     0.7483506
##   mae.test.mean timetrain.test.mean expvar.test.mean
## 1     0.7437658         0.001551724               NA
# what about the residuals ? 
plot(x =  getTaskData(task$task)[["tsa"]], model$residuals[[1]])

Spatialize using the trained a learner

# produce the spatialized geojson
makeSpatialization(model = model$model, name = task$task$task.desc$id, path = "." )
## Writing layer `2017-03-04T150000Z' to data source `./2017-03-04T150000Z.geojson' using driver `GeoJSON'
## features:       33243
## fields:         2
## geometry type:  Point
# read it
data_spatialized = sf::st_read(dsn = paste0(task$task$task.desc$id, ".geojson"))
## Reading layer `OGRGeoJSON' from data source `/home/rstudio/Documents/code/pokyah/agrometeoR/vignettes/2017-03-04T150000Z.geojson' using driver `GeoJSON'
## Simple feature collection with 33243 features and 2 fields
## geometry type:  POINT
## dimension:      XY
## bbox:           xmin: 2.781178 ymin: 49.4953 xmax: 6.405919 ymax: 50.85122
## epsg (SRID):    4326
## proj4string:    +proj=longlat +datum=WGS84 +no_defs

Map the results

# map it ! 
plot(data_spatialized)
